captions.text: I wish to fight as a Spartan, my Lord.
I'm sure that you're worthy but I can not use you.
The fact remains, you're just too deformed to fight.
You are in fact very hideous.
But you said I have a good spear!
I- I wish to fight for you.
and you are denying my offer?
But you're letting all those potters and sculptors fight, they aren't even Spartans!
You're outnumbered a bazillion to one and you're all..
Ohh I can't use you, friend.
But we Spartans fight as one solid unit.
Oh, believe me, we all know what Spartans do with their units!

and I see you guys down there with the
twirly-whirly slow-mo fighting..
It's not always an impenetrable force.

I mean you don't even know me! We
just met dude.

This might be super emotionally scarring
for me!
I'm just trying to make a wise decis--

I might take this rejection way too
harshly.
I may even go to Xerxes' army

revealing the secret path around the
cliffs in exchange for swanky girls.
Did you think about that, Leonidas?
This is the greatest day of my life! Hahahahah!

We're getting pretty tired from
slaughtering all of your men

I'm a little concerned we cannot win
this battle.
I can make you rich and powerful beyond measure..
Such an offer only a mad man would refuse.
I'll give you everything your heart desires.
If you will just kneel at my--

And that is how Leonidas
became president of the universe

I don't think that's historically
accurate.

comments.author: InsaneCoasterPOVs

comments.text:
This movie is really less about real history and more about how the Ancient 
Greeks legitimately saw the invading Persians. Ancient Greek propaganda 
would have you believe that the Persians were a vast horde of monstrous 
slavers. In reality, the Greeks, particularly the "freedom loving" 
Spartans, were some of the most enthusiastic supporters of the slave trade 
of the day. Sparta literally enslaved an entire country; why else do you 
think they had their entire male population in the army?

Persia had slaves too, true enough. But it wasn't quite so totalitarian as 
the movie portrays it. To rule such a vast empire, the Great King had to 
divide it into manageable subdivisions called Satrapies, which were headed 
by regular kings and were administered largely the same as they had been 
before being absorbed by Persia. The Ionian Greeks under Persian rule would 
really not have noticed much of a difference between being independent and 
being under Persian "control."﻿

comments.author: MrDeathangel91

comments.text:
To everyone saying that the movie was historically inaccurate:
In truth, the movie was close in the summary of it. Greeks holding their 
ground against a hopeless number of Persians, eventually lose. That's all 
that's actually important.
What it got wrong was the amount of Greeks. There were only 300 Spartans, 
correct, but there was a rough estimate of 7K militia from other 
city-states (Mainly Athens) with them.
Spartans didn't fight shirtless, they actually had a very iconic set of 
armor, which was why they did as well as they did, better technology and 
the strategy to use it.
I don't exactly know how the Persians figured it out, but they did win 
because of the goat path. They flanked around to end it quickly, although 
they DID have the numbers to just overwhelm the Spartans.
Leonidas and the 300 pushing into Xerxes' camp never happened, they died 
right there in that canyon. However, the survivors, mainly the Athenians 
and a small handful of Spartans, launched a counterattack and took 
Leonidas' body before he could be beheaded.
Here's where the movie ended. So you see, everyone complaining about the 
historical inaccuracy really needs to calm down, because it wasn't far off 
enough to make such a big deal of it.﻿

comments.author: DutchPool

comments.text:
Clearly slavery was one way to make a city state centered on the soldiers 
work because they could devote more time soldiering. We tend to think of 
the Romans as more brutal than the Greeks, but that is doubtful. The whole 
modern idea of 'democracy' (however much of a joke I think it has become in 
the 21st century notwithstanding) is an anachronism when trying to 
understand ancient times.
comments.author: Charles Jannuzi

comments.text:
It could be a good idea to use the background of the Greco-Persian War 
itself, to show the different political systems and societies of the 
various Greek city-states, and the emergence of democracy in Athens. The 
presence of slaves might serve to make a story about the birth of democracy 
in such brutal times quite thought-provoking.

+Charles Jannuzi Aww, this film was never ever going to be history, let's 
face it. I love history, and Thermopylae is one of the great epics of 
manliness and duty. The film was pure popcorn. I mean, an unarmoured 
Spartan is just a wrestler. And that's what the film served up; oily 
wrestlers as fanservice for the girls. The fantastical elements just made 
it even less an attempt at telling history. I'm not going to knock it for 
not doing something which it was never trying to do anyway. For that, I'll 
watch The 300 Spartans, not a perfect movie, but sword & sandals as it used 
to be done.
